text.text:
You can find all manner of noodle soups in the big bad world, but today's tale begins with young phò. Originally from North Vietnam, it started off pretty simple, with a simmering broth of leftover beef bones, rice noodles and various spices.

When the country was partitioned in 1985, lots of people moved south to avoid the communist regime. That's when our young phò was influenced by a bunch of new ingredients leading to many a variation of hot brothy goodness.

tip.text:
You won't find the designery interiors and fusion menus of Shoreditch's Vietnamese restaurants at this authentic Vietnamese cafe. But what you will find are steaming bowls of flagrant pho noodle soup and fresh rice bowls topped with grilled lemongrass pork.

Food is served in a simple setting and due to it's popularity, it isn't rare to share your table with fellow pho slurpers.

text.text: You've probably heard of phò, mainly because of that one friend who tried it on her gap year and has never shut up about it since. Keep it simple with this phò tai chin, filled with (tai) rare and (chin) well-done beef. The broth is made with chicken and beef bones so it's leaner and milder than other phòs.

tip.text: This Vietnamese is a far cry from the sloppy places you sometimes find yourself in accidentally. They do all the classic recipes with fresh ingredients so you get all the zesty flavours of authentic Vietnamese food. Go for a warming pho or the slow-cooked chicken with ginger, chilli and lemongrass. Finish with their Vietnamese iced coffee, made with condensed milk.

text.text: If like the local Buddhist monks you're after some veg, try an assorted mushroom pho. Com Viet make it with shiitake mushrooms, oyster mushrooms and 'chouchou'. Chouchou, also known as chayote, is kinda like the illegitimate lovechild of a cucumber and a potato. It's an ugly child, with a squashed face. Google it.

tip.text:
If you're looking for a slice of Ho Chi Minh, then that's exactly what you're going to get here...

Sugar, spice and everything nice can be found on the menu in the shape of generously sized noodle portions, crispy pancakes and dumplings. We reckon you should give the Banh Xeo a whirl – Vietnamese Crispy Pancake with Pork Belly, Prawns and a Nuoc Mam Chua Sauce. Wash it all back with a tasty champagne, elderflower and gin cocktail.

text.text: Many Vietnamese restaurants will have several phò – ranging from clean flavours, (verging on bland) to meat sweat inducing richness. This phò dac biet is at the richer end of the scale with beef broth, beef short rib, bulgogi beef and roasted bone marrow. It might be the spenniest there but that bone marrow is worth it. Smooth creamy slurping for you.

tip.text:
Different cultures have different solutions to sin... but in London, a trip to this Vietnamese joint should do it. Salvation in Noodles in North London is a popular spot for great noodles, Vietnamese fish cakes, and a host of local heroes like Dalston Cola.

The menu is emblazoned with pictures of the Virgin Mary and other sin-redeeming imagery. We're not sure why, but instead of trying to figure it out, we recommend focusing on the food, which is bang on.

text.text: We're upping the ante a little with a mì quảng topped with melt in your mouth pork belly, prawns and a soft boiled egg. That's a lot of protein for one bowl, but it's nicely balanced by fresh chillies and rice noodles still yellow from being cooked in turmeric. We wouldn't have a starter with this one, but if you can't resist a little sumin' sumin', their taro chips are a real crowd pleaser.

tip.text:
This Vietnamese is very different from the spots you know along Kingsland Road. It may be a little more spenny but it’s a whole lot more spacious, dishes feel considered, and drinks are exciting. We plumped for Fritz-Kola and Saigon special beer - both mighty refreshing.

Mama Pham is the head chef and matriarch. She comes up with new menu items, oversees marinades and just generally kills it while her son Robert sees to front of house. Hit up the reliable and warming pho or make your own summer rolls. Dip your rice paper in the warm water, lay out the sheet, fill it with all things pork, mint and coriander then wrap and roll. Were our rolls anywhere close to profesh looking? No. Did they taste fresh and summery once dipped in chilli sauce? Oh yes.

text.text: Now shit is getting real spicy and there's no hiding from it. This traditional soup from the imperial city of Hue is made with a thicker vermicelli noodle, tender beef brisket, and pork belly in a rich and spicy beef broth infused with lemon grass. Get your tissues out and prepare for the release of sweat and endorphins.

tip.text:
While you're definitely spoilt for choice with Vietnamese food on this strip of Kingsland Road, this sweet, family run restaurant might just be the pick of the bunch. Hanoi Cafe has by far the most welcoming interior: the left-side walls are lined with colourful, post-war propaganda posters from the nation, while the right-side boasts stunning black and white photos of the family.

Don't know what to eat? Everything in here is made with lovely, fresh ingredients and dishes are packed full of flavour and a pinch of spice. Light and tasty summer rolls; authentic 'bun' vermicelli noodle salads; and crunchy baguettes, packed with grilled pork and veg, all make deciding difficult. Your problem, not ours. The £6 lunch deal is an absolute no brainer.

text.text: This hot and sour soup would typically be made in the Mekong Delta region of Southern Vietnam with fish from the Mekong river. Hot and sour? The spice comes from chillies of course and the sour taste from a small amount of tamarind essence mixed in. That and all the fresh herbs, and you've got yourself some serious zing.
